But you shall be desolate forever,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set up a banner in the land,
Blow the trumpet among the nations!
Prepare the nations against her,
Call the kingdoms together against her:
Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz.
Appoint a general against her;
Cause the horses to come up like the bristling locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Prepare against her the nations,
With the kings of the Medes,
Its governors and all its rulers,
All the land of his dominion.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The passages are blocked,
The reeds they have burned with fire,
And the men of war are terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel:
“The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor
When it is time to thresh her;
Yet a little while
And the time of her harvest will come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Let the violence done to me and my flesh be upon Babylon,”
The inhabitant of Zion will say;
“And my blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea!”
Jerusalem will say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore thus says the Lord:
“Behold, I will plead your case and take vengeance for you.
I will dry up her sea and make her springs dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon shall become a heap,
A dwelling place for jackals,
An astonishment and a hissing,
Without an inhabitant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They shall roar together like lions,
They shall growl like lions’ whelps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In their excitement I will prepare their feasts;
I will make them drunk,
That they may rejoice,
And sleep a perpetual sleep
And not awake,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I will bring them down
Like lambs to the slaughter,
Like rams with male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Oh, how Sheshach is taken!
Oh, how the praise of the whole earth is seized!
How Babylon has become desolate among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sea has come up over Babylon;
She is covered with the multitude of its waves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her cities are a desolation,
A dry land and a wilderness,
A land where no one dwells,
Through which no son of man passes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will punish Bel in Babylon,
And I will bring out of his mouth what he has swallowed;
And the nations shall not stream to him anymore.
Yes, the wall of Babylon shall fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“My people, go out of the midst of her!
And let everyone deliver himself from the fierce anger of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And lest your heart faint,
And you fear for the rumor that will be heard in the land
(A rumor will come one year,
And after that, in another year
A rumor will come,
And violence in the land,
Ruler against ruler),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore behold, the days are coming
That I will bring judgment on the carved images of Babylon;
Her whole land shall be ashamed,
And all her slain shall fall in her midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
As Babylon has caused the slain of Israel to fall,
So at Babylon the slain of all the earth shall fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who have escaped the sword,
Get away! Do not stand still!
Remember the Lord afar off,
And let Jerusalem come to your mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We are ashamed because we have heard reproach.
Shame has covered our faces,
For strangers have come into the sanctuaries of the Lord’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore behold, the days are coming,” says the Lord,
“That I will bring judgment on her carved images,
And throughout all her land the wounded shall groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though Babylon were to mount up to heaven,
And though she were to fortify the height of her strength,
Yet from Me plunderers would come to her,” says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sound of a cry comes from Babylon,
And great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because the Lord is plundering Babylon
And silencing her loud voice,
Though her waves roar like great waters,
And the noise of their voice is uttered,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because the plunderer comes against her, against Babylon,
And her mighty men are taken.
Every one of their bows is broken;
For the Lord is the God of recompense,
He will surely repay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And I will make drunk
Her princes and wise men,
Her governors, her deputies, and her mighty men.
And they shall sleep a perpetual sleep
And not awake,” says the King,
Whose name is the Lord of hosts.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: The word which Jeremiah the prophet commanded Seraiah the son of Neriah, the son of Mahseiah, when he went with Zedekiah the king of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. And Seraiah was the quartermaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah wrote in a book all the evil that would come upon Babylon, all these words that are written against Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jeremiah said to Seraiah, “When you arrive in Babylon and see it, and read all these words,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you shall say, ‘O Lord, You have spoken against this place to cut it off, so that none shall remain in it, neither man nor beast, but it shall be desolate forever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it shall be, when you have finished reading this book, that you shall tie a stone to it and throw it out into the Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then you shall say, ‘Thus Babylon shall sink and not rise from the catastrophe that I will bring upon her. And they shall be weary.’ ”
Thus far are the words of Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also did evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that Jehoiakim had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For because of the anger of the Lord this happened in Jerusalem and Judah, till He finally cast them out from His presence. Then Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it came to pass in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and all his army came against Jerusalem and encamped against it; and they built a siege wall against it all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the city was besieged until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the fourth month, on the ninth day of the month, the famine had become so severe in the city that there was no food for the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the city wall was broken through, and all the men of war fled and went out of the city at night by way of the gate between the two walls, which was by the king’s garden, even though the Chaldeans were near the city all around. And they went by way of the plain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king, and they overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. All his army was scattered from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, and he pronounced judgment on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Babylon killed the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes. And he killed all the princes of Judah in Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also put out the eyes of Zedekiah; and the king of Babylon bound him in bronze fetters, took him to Babylon, and put him in prison till the day of his death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now in the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month (which was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon), Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, who served the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the house of the Lord and the king’s house; all the houses of Jerusalem, that is, all the houses of the great, he burned with fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the guard broke down all the walls of Jerusalem all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried away captive some of the poor people, the rest of the people who remained in the city, the defectors who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the craftsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left some of the poor of the land as vinedressers and farmers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bronze pillars that were in the house of the Lord, and the carts and the bronze Sea that were in the house of the Lord, the Chaldeans broke in pieces, and carried all their bronze to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also took away the pots, the shovels, the trimmers, the bowls, the spoons, and all the bronze utensils with which the priests ministered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The basins, the firepans, the bowls, the pots, the lampstands, the spoons, and the cups, whatever was solid gold and whatever was solid silver, the captain of the guard took away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two pillars, one Sea, the twelve bronze bulls which were under it, and the carts, which King Solomon had made for the house of the Lord—the bronze of all these articles was beyond measure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now concerning the pillars: the height of one pillar was eighteen cubits, a measuring line of twelve cubits could measure its circumference, and its thickness was four fingers; it was hollow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A capital of bronze was on it; and the height of one capital was five cubits, with a network and pomegranates all around the capital, all of bronze. The second pillar, with pomegranates was the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides; all the pomegranates, all around on the network, were one hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three doorkeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also took out of the city an officer who had charge of the men of war, seven men of the king’s close associates who were found in the city, the principal scribe of the army who mustered the people of the land, and sixty men of the people of the land who were found in the midst of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took these and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Babylon struck them and put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. Thus Judah was carried away captive from its own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the people whom Nebuchadnezzar carried away captive: in the seventh year, three thousand and twenty-three Jews;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar he carried away captive from Jerusalem eight hundred and thirty-two persons;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the twenty-third year of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried away captive of the Jews seven hundred and forty-five persons. All the persons were four thousand six hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it came to pass in the thirty-seventh year of the captivity of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth day of the month, that Evil-Merodach king of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, lifted up the head of Jehoiachin king of Judah and brought him out of prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he spoke kindly to him and gave him a more prominent seat than those of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoiachin changed from his prison garments, and he ate bread regularly before the king all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as for his provisions, there was a regular ration given him by the king of Babylon, a portion for each day until the day of his death, all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator
